8.text:
What an honour it is to be performing for his
Royal Highness, thank you very much.

12.text:
Particularly as before I did stand-up, I used
to make my living as a Prince Harry look-alike.

20.text:
I sort of worry, Prince Harry looks gorgeous,
my wife really does quite fancy you.

28.text: I'm putting on a lot of weight, I'm worried about it.

30.text: I'm very self-conscious about my body.

33.text:
Just recently, I woke up one morning,
I went to the bathroom.

36.text:
I looked at my chocolate
blancmange torso in the mirror.

42.text:
I went back to the bedroom and I
apologised to my wife for my appearance.

51.text:
I tried to put a positive spin on it.
I said to my wife:

53.text: "Do you know what? I've grown this for you.

56.text: I've grown this to take myself out of the game.

67.text: The truth is, I love my wife, I do love her very much.

69.text:
She deserves better than me,
but I cannot be bothered to provide it.

81.text:
I'm thinking to myself:
"I don't have to be an excellent husband.

84.text:
I just have to be slightly less annoying
than starting divorce proceedings."

87.text: I feel that's the way I'm gonna operate.

91.text: I am married to a white woman.

93.text:
I'm telling you that because it's essential
for the story, I'm not showing off.

101.text: My brother is also married to a white woman.

103.text: A different one, we don't roll like that.

107.text: But, last Christmas, my mother invited us all round for Christmas dinner. Absolutely delightful.

113.text: She invited my wife's family, she invited my sister-in-law's family, they all come round for Christmas dinner.

122.text:
She did two dinners. She did a traditional
turkey dinner, and she did a curry.

126.text: And she said: "Just sit near the one you want."

131.text:
Our Christmas dinner table looked like a bus
pre-Rosa Parks, it was absolutely insane.

137.text:
[Sri Lankan accent] Merry Christmas,
welcome to our apartheid simulation!

141.text:
Oh, no, no, whitey! You're gonna have a horrible
Boxing Day if you eat that, too spicy for you.

152.text: I do love my wife, I'm not good enough for that woman.

155.text: That's the honest truth of it, I'm not good enough.

156.text: I've realised recently, I'm a fake feminist.

160.text: I don't know if there are any of those in the room.

162.text:
But basically what I mean by that is, I say
all the right things, but

166.text: I don't know if I mean it.

169.text:
Like I'll say to my wife I wanna help her achieve
her dreams, hopes and aspirations, but

173.text:
it would be a lot more convenient
to me if she didn't have any.

187.text: You shouldn't be proud at whooping at that, mate.

191.text:
But the thing is, what that does, is it makes me
wanna step up, and prove myself to my wife

195.text:
It makes me wanna step up
and do the right thing by her,

198.text:
and I had the opportunity to step up for our family,
because our eldest son had to go to school.

203.text: And we had to choose a school for our son.

205.text:
And I said to my wife: "You know what,
I know I don't do enough.

208.text:
I'd like to step up and choose a school for our son.
I'd like to be in charge of this operation."

213.text:
To cut a long story short, I chose a school that was shut down
for not meeting government requirements.

217.text: Now, that is a difficult situation but in fairness to me,

221.text: Why are we having to make qualitative judgements about schools? Here's a solution:

225.text: Make them all good, I'll pick the nearest one. Alright?

235.text:
Why would you not want to invest more
money in making the future less thick?

244.text: Morons are taking over, aren't they?

247.text: And they're reproducing more quickly than us.

251.text:
For every intelligent person using a condom,
there are two dipsticks using clingfilm.

260.text: "I've used the whole roll, I think it's go-time!" You know...

264.text: I'm helping my eldest son learn to read, actually.

266.text:
I don't know if anyone here has
helped a child learn to read.

270.text: It is one of the most... Have you done it?

275.text:
It's one of the most magical and rewarding
things I think you can do as a parent.

280.text: The first time that you do it.

286.text:
After that it's one of the most
irritating, annoying, waste-of-time,

297.text: And let me tell you why.

299.text: He does not care, this kid, about making sense!

303.text:
He'll just rattle off the words. All the little ones
"If, and, but, da-da-da-da-da..."

308.text:
Rattle those off. When he gets to a long word, a difficult word,
instead of trying, he'll just look at the picture

315.text: and throw something random in from there.

318.text:
without any regard for what effect
that has on the rest of the sentence.

324.text: And I'm supposed to not get angry!

327.text: I'm supposed to not get angry when he goes:

337.text: How could that possibly be what it said, mate?

340.text:
Out of all the words that you know,
how could it, in any way, have been strawberry?

347.text:
What about this story made you think that
the next thing that Jack was gonna do was go strawberry?

352.text:
Have you even heard that phrase?
Have you ever heard mummy saying "I'm off to go strawberry"?

356.text:
Have you ever heard it? 
So, what was going on in your head?

358.text: What would that even look like, Jack going strawberry?

360.text:
What would it look like?
Now you tell me, what would it look like!?

363.text:
I tell you what, if you think that's what it said,
why don't you go strawberry now.
Go on, you go strawberry now.

368.text:
Stop crying, go strawberry! Because
that's what you said it said! I didn't say it!

373.text: If I said it I'd be going strawberry all over the shop, mate!

382.text:
My wife thinks I'm overreacting, right,
and I know that that looks bad.

387.text:
I realise that, but let me tell you this,
it comes from a good place.

390.text:
I want my son to be educated. I want him to have
the world at his feet. I don't want him to be a moron.

394.text:
I don't want to knock on his door in 20 years time,
he opens it, he's just scratching himself:

402.text: I say to him: "What's wrong with you?"

403.text: He says: "I think I'm allergic to clingfilm."

407.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, I've been Romesh Ranganathan.
Thank you, good night!
